abstract: Editorial observes crime has remained at historic lows across New York City despite dramatic reduction in Police Dept's use of aggressive tactics, including 'stop-and-frisk' policy; notes report from John Jay College of Criminal Justice showing 31 percent drop in such actions between 2011 and 2014, with 93 percent drop in street stops; holds numbers contradict warnings that reduction in aggressive policing would lead to crime spike; contends next important step is to ensure respectful relations with at-risk communities.
lead_paragraph: A new report shows how drastically policing practices in the city have changed since 2011 — even as crime rates remain historically low.

headline.main: New York City Policing, by the Numbers
headline.print_headline: New York Policing, by the Numbers

snippet: A new report shows how drastically policing practices in the city have changed since 2011 — even as crime rates remain historically low.
